# Oval Office

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

For the NASCAR command station, see [Oval Office
(NASCAR)](/wiki/Oval_Office_\(NASCAR\) "Oval Office \(NASCAR\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_43_%2834252543421%29.jpg/330px-
President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_43_%2834252543421%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_43_\(34252543421\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_43_\(34252543421\).jpg
"Enlarge")

President [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") meets with (from
left) [U.S. Secretary of Health and Human
Services](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Health_and_Human_Services "United
States Secretary of Health and Human Services") [Tom
Price](/wiki/Tom_Price_\(American_politician\) "Tom Price \(American
politician\)"); [Vice President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States
"Vice President of the United States") [Mike Pence](/wiki/Mike_Pence "Mike
Pence"); [Speaker of the
House](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives "Speaker of
the United States House of Representatives") [Paul Ryan](/wiki/Paul_Ryan "Paul
Ryan"); [Dr. Zeke Emanuel](/wiki/Ezekiel_Emanuel "Ezekiel Emanuel"); and
Director of [Domestic Policy
Council](/wiki/United_States_Domestic_Policy_Council "United States Domestic

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Oval_Office_1981.jpg/220px-
Oval_Office_1981.jpg)](/wiki/File:Oval_Office_1981.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Oval_Office_1981.jpg "Enlarge")

The Oval Office in 1981

The **Oval Office** is the working [office](/wiki/Office "Office") space of
the [President of the United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States
"President of the United States") located in the [West Wing](/wiki/West_Wing
"West Wing") of the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House"),
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.").

The room features three large south-facing windows behind the president's
desk, and a fireplace at the north end. It has four doors: the east door opens
to the [Rose Garden](/wiki/White_House_Rose_Garden "White House Rose Garden");
the west door leads to a [private study](/wiki/Oval_Office_Study "Oval Office
Study") and dining room; the northwest door opens onto the main corridor of
the [West Wing](/wiki/West_Wing "West Wing"); and the northeast door opens to
the office of the president's secretary.

Presidents generally decorate the office to suit their personal taste,
choosing new furniture, new drapery, and designing their own oval-shaped
carpet to take up most of the floor. Artwork is selected from the White
House's own collection, or borrowed from museums for the president's term in
office.

## Cultural
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Cultural history")]

The Oval Office has become associated in Americans' minds with the presidency
itself through memorable images, such as a young [John F. Kennedy,
Jr.](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy,_Jr. "John F. Kennedy, Jr.") peering through the
front panel of his father's desk, President [Richard
Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") speaking by telephone with the
[Apollo 11](/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") astronauts during their moonwalk, and
daughter [Amy Carter](/wiki/Amy_Carter "Amy Carter") bringing her Siamese cat
Misty Malarky Ying Yang to brighten President [Jimmy
Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter")'s day. Several presidents have
[addressed the nation from the Oval Office](/wiki/Oval_Office_address "Oval
Office address") on occasion. Examples include Kennedy presenting news of the
[Cuban Missile Crisis](/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis "Cuban Missile Crisis")
(1962), Nixon [announcing his resignation from
office](/wiki/SP_3-125:_Richard_Nixon%27s_address_announcing_his_intention_to_resign_the_presidency
"SP 3-125: Richard Nixon's address announcing his intention to resign the
presidency") (1974),[1] [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan")
following the [Space Shuttle _Challenger_
disaster](/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Challenger_Disaster "Space Shuttle Challenger
Disaster") (1986),[2] and [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W.
Bush") in the wake of the [September 11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks
"September 11 attacks") (2001).[3] In 2018, former White House stenographer
[Beck Dorey-Stein](/wiki/Beck_Dorey-Stein "Beck Dorey-Stein") published a
memoir about her years working for Obama called "[From the Corner of the
Oval](https://www.amazon.com/Corner-Oval-Memoir-Beck-Dorey-
Stein/dp/0525509127)."

## Antecedents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Antecedents")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/PhiladelphiaPresidentsHouse.jpg/210px-
PhiladelphiaPresidentsHouse.jpg)](/wiki/File:PhiladelphiaPresidentsHouse.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PhiladelphiaPresidentsHouse.jpg "Enlarge")

[President's House](/wiki/President%27s_House_\(Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania\)
"President's House \(Philadelphia, Pennsylvania\)"), Philadelphia,
Pennsylvania. George Washington's Bow Window (not depicted) is echoed in the
shape of the Oval Office.

### Washington's Bow
Window[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Washington's Bow Window")]

[George Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington") never
occupied the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House"). He spent most of
his presidency in [Philadelphia,
Pennsylvania](/wiki/Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania "Philadelphia, Pennsylvania"),
which served as the temporary national capital for 10 years, 1790–1800, while
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") was under
construction.

In 1790, Washington built a large, two-story, semi-circular addition to the
rear of the [President's House in
Philadelphia](/wiki/President%27s_House_\(Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania\)
"President's House \(Philadelphia, Pennsylvania\)"), creating a ceremonial
space in which the public would meet the President.[4] Standing before the
three windows of this Bow Window, he formally received guests for his Tuesday
afternoon [levees](/wiki/Audience_\(meeting\) "Audience \(meeting\)"),
delegations from Congress and foreign dignitaries, and the general public at
open houses on [New Year's Day](/wiki/New_Year%27s_Day "New Year's Day"), the
[Fourth of July](/wiki/Fourth_of_July "Fourth of July"), and his birthday.

> "Washington received his guests, standing between the windows in his back
> drawing-room. The company, entering a front room and passing through an
> unfolding door, made their salutations to the President, and turning off,
> stood on one side."[5]

President [John Adams](/wiki/John_Adams "John Adams") occupied the
Philadelphia mansion beginning in March 1797, and used the Bow Window in the
same manner as his predecessor.[6]

Curved foundations of Washington's Bow Window were uncovered during a 2007
archaeological excavation of the [President's
House](/wiki/President%27s_House_\(Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania\) "President's
House \(Philadelphia, Pennsylvania\)") site.[7] They are exhibited under glass
at the President's House Commemoration, just north of the [Liberty Bell
Center](/wiki/Liberty_Bell_Center "Liberty Bell Center").[8]

### White House[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: White House")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Yellow_Oval_Room_1886.jpg/210px-
Yellow_Oval_Room_1886.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yellow_Oval_Room_1886.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Yellow_Oval_Room_1886.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Yellow Oval Room](/wiki/Yellow_Oval_Room "Yellow Oval Room") as President
[Grover Cleveland](/wiki/Grover_Cleveland "Grover Cleveland")'s library and
study, 1886. Note his use of the [_Resolute_ desk](/wiki/Resolute_Desk
"Resolute Desk").

Architect [James Hoban](/wiki/James_Hoban "James Hoban") visited President
Washington in Philadelphia in June 1792 and would have seen the Bow Window.[9]
The following month, he was named winner of the design competition for [The
White House](/wiki/The_White_House "The White House").

The "elliptic salon" at the center of the White House was the outstanding
feature of Hoban's original plan. An oval interior space was a
[Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") concept that was adapted by
[Neoclassicism](/wiki/Neoclassicism "Neoclassicism"). Oval rooms became
popular in eighteenth century neoclassical architecture.

In November 1800, [John Adams](/wiki/John_Adams "John Adams") became the first
President to occupy the White House. He and his successor, President [Thomas
Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson"), used Hoban's oval rooms
in the same ceremonial manner that Washington had used the Bow Window,
standing before the three windows at the south end to receive guests.[10]

During the 19th century, a number of presidents used the White House's second-
floor [Yellow Oval Room](/wiki/Yellow_Oval_Room_\(White_House\) "Yellow Oval
Room \(White House\)") as a private office or library.

### West Wing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: West Wing")]

The [West Wing](/wiki/West_Wing "West Wing") was the idea of President
[Theodore Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore Roosevelt"), brought
about by his wife's opinion that the second floor of the White House, then
shared between bedrooms and offices, should be just a domestic space. The one-
story Executive Office Building was intended to be a temporary structure, for
use until a permanent building was erected either on that site or
elsewhere.[11] Building it to the west of the White House allowed the removal
of a vast, dilapidated set of pre-[Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War
"American Civil War") greenhouses that had been constructed by President
[James Buchanan](/wiki/James_Buchanan "James Buchanan").[12] Roosevelt moved
the offices of the [executive branch](/wiki/Executive_branch "Executive
branch") to the newly constructed wing in 1902. His workspace was a two-room
suite of Executive Office and Cabinet Room, located just west of the present
[Cabinet Room](/wiki/Cabinet_Room_\(White_House\) "Cabinet Room \(White
House\)"). The furniture, including the [president's
desk](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt_desk "Theodore Roosevelt desk"), was designed
by architect [Charles Follen McKim](/wiki/Charles_Follen_McKim "Charles Follen
McKim") and executed by [A. H. Davenport and
Company](/wiki/A._H._Davenport_and_Company "A. H. Davenport and Company"), of
Boston.[13]

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/WH2Yellow.png/120px-WH2Yellow.png)](/wiki/File:WH2Yellow.png)

Location of the [Yellow Oval Room](/wiki/Yellow_Oval_Room "Yellow Oval Room")
on the second floor of the White House. A number of presidents used this as
their private office or library.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Yellow-oval-room-c1868.jpg/120px-Yellow-oval-room-c1868.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yellow-oval-room-c1868.jpg)

The [Yellow Oval Room](/wiki/Yellow_Oval_Room "Yellow Oval Room") about 1868
used as President [Andrew Johnson](/wiki/Andrew_Johnson "Andrew Johnson")'s
library. Note the bearskin chair on the right.

## Taft Oval Office:
1909–1933[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Taft Oval Office: 1909–1933")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/TaftOval1909.jpg/210px-
TaftOval1909.jpg)](/wiki/File:TaftOval1909.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TaftOval1909.jpg "Enlarge")

Taft Oval Office, completed 1909. Nearly identical in size to the modern
office, it was damaged by fire in 1929 and demolished in 1933.

President [William Howard Taft](/wiki/William_Howard_Taft "William Howard
Taft") made the West Wing a permanent building, expanding it southward,
doubling its size, and building the first Oval Office.[14] Designed by [Nathan
C. Wyeth](/wiki/Nathan_C._Wyeth "Nathan C. Wyeth") and completed in 1909, the
office was centered on the south side of the building, much as the oval rooms
in the White House are. Taft intended it to be the hub of his administration,
and, by locating it in the center of the West Wing, he could be more involved
with the day-to-day operation of his presidency. The Taft Oval Office had
simple Georgian Revival trim, and was likely the most colorful in history; the
walls were covered with vibrant seagrass green burlap.[15]

On December 24, 1929, during President [Herbert Hoover](/wiki/Herbert_Hoover
"Herbert Hoover")'s administration, a fire severely damaged the West Wing.
Hoover used this as an opportunity to create more space, excavating a partial
basement for additional offices. He restored the Oval Office, upgrading the
quality of trim and installing air-conditioning. He also replaced the
furniture, which had undergone no major changes in twenty years.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/West_Wing_between_1910_and_1920_cropped.jpg/120px-West_Wing_between_1910_and_1920_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:West_Wing_between_1910_and_1920_cropped.jpg)

Exterior of the West Wing (circa 1910s), showing the curve of the Taft Oval
Office.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/President_Hoover_views_West_Wing_fire_ruins_15_January_1930_cropped.jpg/120px-President_Hoover_views_West_Wing_fire_ruins_15_January_1930_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:President_Hoover_views_West_Wing_fire_ruins_15_January_1930_cropped.jpg)

President Hoover views West Wing fire ruins, January 15, 1930.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/West-wing-1934-construction.jpg/120px-West-wing-1934-construction.jpg)](/wiki/File:West-wing-1934-construction.jpg)

West Wing construction, 1934.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Oval_Office_Exterior.jpg/120px-Oval_Office_Exterior.jpg)](/wiki/File:Oval_Office_Exterior.jpg)

Exterior of the Oval Office as viewed from the South Lawn, July 15, 2006.

## Modern Oval Office:
1934–present[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Modern Oval Office: 1934–present")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/White_House_West_Wing_-_1st_Floor_with_the_Oval_Office_highlighted.png/230px-
White_House_West_Wing_-_1st_Floor_with_the_Oval_Office_highlighted.png)](/wiki/File:White_House_West_Wing_-_1st_Floor_with_the_Oval_Office_highlighted.png)

[](/wiki/File:White_House_West_Wing_-_1st_Floor_with_the_Oval_Office_highlighted.png
"Enlarge")

Location of the Oval Office in the [West Wing](/wiki/West_Wing "West Wing").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/FDR_Oval_Office_in_1934_LOC37952v_cropped.jpg/230px-
FDR_Oval_Office_in_1934_LOC37952v_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:FDR_Oval_Office_in_1934_LOC37952v_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FDR_Oval_Office_in_1934_LOC37952v_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

The newly built FDR Oval Office in 1934.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/OvalMedallion.jpg/230px-
OvalMedallion.jpg)](/wiki/File:OvalMedallion.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:OvalMedallion.jpg "Enlarge")

Plaster ceiling medallion installed in 1934 includes elements of the [Seal of
the President of the United
States](/wiki/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States "Seal of the
President of the United States").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/REAGANEugeniaCharles.jpg/220px-
REAGANEugeniaCharles.jpg)](/wiki/File:REAGANEugeniaCharles.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:REAGANEugeniaCharles.jpg "Enlarge")

[Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") discussing Grenada with
Prime Minister [Eugenia Charles](/wiki/Eugenia_Charles "Eugenia Charles") of
[Dominica](/wiki/Dominica "Dominica") in the Oval Office

Dissatisfied with the size and layout of the West Wing, President [Franklin D.
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt") engaged New
York architect [Eric Gugler](/wiki/Eric_Gugler "Eric Gugler") to redesign it
in 1933. To create additional space without increasing the apparent size of
the building, Gugler excavated a full basement, added a set of subterranean
offices under the adjacent lawn, and built an unobtrusive "penthouse" story.
The directive to wring the most office space out of the existing building was
responsible for its narrow corridors and cramped staff offices. Gugler's most
visible addition was the expansion of the building eastward for a new Cabinet
Room and Oval Office.[16]

The modern Oval Office was built at the West Wing's southeast corner, offering
FDR, who was physically disabled and used a [wheelchair](/wiki/Wheelchair
"Wheelchair"), more privacy and easier access to the Residence. He and Gugler
devised a room architecturally grander than the previous two rooms, with more
robust Georgian details: doors topped with substantial pediments, bookcases
set into niches, a deep bracketed cornice, and a ceiling medallion of the
[Presidential Seal](/wiki/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States "Seal of
the President of the United States"). Rather than a chandelier or ceiling
fixture, the room is illuminated by light bulbs hidden within the cornice that
"wash" the ceiling in light.[17] In small ways, hints of [Art
Moderne](/wiki/Art_Moderne "Art Moderne") can be seen, in the sconces flanking
the windows and the representation of the eagle in the ceiling medallion. FDR
and Gugler worked closely together, often over breakfast, with Gugler
sketching the president's ideas. One notion resulting from these sketches that
has become fixed in the layout of the room's furniture, is that of two high
back chairs in front of the fireplace. The public sees this most often with
the president seated on the left, and a visiting head of state on the right.
This allowed FDR to be seated, with his guests at the same level, de-
emphasizing his inability to stand. Construction of the modern Oval Office was
completed in 1934.

### Decoration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Decoration")]

The basic Oval Office furnishings have been a desk in front of the three
windows at the south end, a pair of chairs in front of the fireplace at the
north end, a pair of sofas, and assorted tables and chairs. The
[Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture")
mantel was made for the Taft Oval Office in 1909, and salvaged after the 1929
West Wing fire.[18] A tradition of displaying potted Swedish ivy
(_[Plectranthus verticillatus](/wiki/Plectranthus_verticillatus "Plectranthus
verticillatus")_) atop the [mantel](/wiki/Fireplace_mantel "Fireplace mantel")
goes back to the administration of [John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy
"John F. Kennedy"), and the current plants were rooted from the original
plant.

A [Federal](/wiki/Federal_furniture "Federal furniture") longcase clock, made
in Boston by John and Thomas Seymour c. 1795–1805 – commonly known as the
[Oval Office grandfather clock](/wiki/Oval_Office_grandfather_clock "Oval
Office grandfather clock") – was purchased by the White House Historical
Association in 1972, and has stood next to the Oval Office's northeast door
since 1975.[19]

The carpet of the Oval Office bears the [Seal of the
President](/wiki/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States "Seal of the
President of the United States"). President [Harry S.
Truman](/wiki/Harry_S._Truman "Harry S. Truman")'s oval carpet was the first
to incorporate the presidential seal. In Truman's carpet, the seal was
represented monochromatically through varying depths of the cut pile. His
carpet was used in the Eisenhower and Kennedy administrations. In recent years
most administrations have created their own rug, working with an interior
designer and the [Curator of the White
House](/wiki/White_House_Office_of_the_Curator "White House Office of the
Curator"). As part of her overall restoration of the White House, Jacqueline
Kennedy had a redecoration of the Oval Office begun on November 21, 1963, when
she accompanied President John F. Kennedy on a trip to Texas. The next day,
November 22, a new carpet was installed just as the Kennedys were making their
way through Dallas and the President was assassinated.[20]

#### Desks[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Desks")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Caroline_Kennedy_Kerry_Kennedy_Resolute_Desk_a.jpg/220px-
Caroline_Kennedy_Kerry_Kennedy_Resolute_Desk_a.jpg)](/wiki/File:Caroline_Kennedy_Kerry_Kennedy_Resolute_Desk_a.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Caroline_Kennedy_Kerry_Kennedy_Resolute_Desk_a.jpg "Enlarge")

[Caroline Kennedy](/wiki/Caroline_Kennedy "Caroline Kennedy") and [Kerry
Kennedy](/wiki/Kerry_Kennedy "Kerry Kennedy") beneath the [_Resolute_
desk](/wiki/Resolute_desk "Resolute desk") in 1963

[Six desks](/wiki/List_of_Oval_Office_desks "List of Oval Office desks") have
been used in the Oval Office by U.S. Presidents. The [Theodore Roosevelt
desk](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt_desk "Theodore Roosevelt desk") was used there
by seven presidents – most recently by Dwight Eisenhower – and by Theodore
Roosevelt in his non-oval office.

Equally popular is the [_Resolute_ Desk](/wiki/Resolute_Desk "Resolute Desk"),
so named because it was made from the timbers of the British frigate [HMS
_Resolute_](/wiki/HMS_Resolute_\(1850\) "HMS Resolute \(1850\)"). The ship had
been frozen in [Arctic](/wiki/Arctic "Arctic") ice and abandoned but was later
found and freed by American seamen. It was refurbished and presented as a gift
from the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") to [Queen
Victoria](/wiki/Victoria_of_the_United_Kingdom "Victoria of the United
Kingdom") in 1856. When the ship was decommissioned from the [British
Navy](/wiki/British_Navy "British Navy") in 1879, Queen Victoria ordered twin
desks made from its timbers, keeping one and presenting the other as a gift to
President [Rutherford B. Hayes](/wiki/Rutherford_B._Hayes "Rutherford B.
Hayes") in 1880. President [Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt
"Franklin D. Roosevelt") ordered a kneehole panel with the [Presidential
Seal](/wiki/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States "Seal of the President
of the United States") added, but work was not completed until after his 1945
death in office. First Lady [Jacqueline Kennedy](/wiki/Jacqueline_Kennedy
"Jacqueline Kennedy") had the desk restored, and she was the first to place it
in the Oval Office. Following the 1963 assassination of President [John F.
Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy"), the desk toured the country
as part of a traveling exhibit for the [Kennedy Presidential
Library](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Library "John F. Kennedy Library") and was then
lent to the [Smithsonian Institution](/wiki/Smithsonian_Institution
"Smithsonian Institution"). President [Jimmy Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy
Carter") brought the desk back to the Oval Office in the 1970s. Since then,
Presidents [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan"), [Bill
Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton"), [George W.
Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush"), [Barack
Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") and [Donald
Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") have also used it as their Oval
Office desk.

When not in use in the Oval Office, a desk is often placed in the adjacent
Oval Office Study, in the White House, or is used by the vice-president.

#### Artwork[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Artwork")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/OvalFloor.jpg/220px-
OvalFloor.jpg)](/wiki/File:OvalFloor.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:OvalFloor.jpg "Enlarge")

Oval Office floor, replaced during the administration of [Ronald
Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan"). Designed by Nancy Reagan, the
installation is arranged in a contrasting cross pattern of [quarter
sawn](/wiki/Quarter_sawn "Quarter sawn") oak and walnut.

Decorator Ted Graber arranged for the floor to be built, installed and donated
by Rode Brothers from Los Angeles .

Art may be selected from the White House collection, or may be borrowed from
museums or individuals for the length of an administration.

Most presidents have hung a portrait of George Washington – usually the
[Rembrandt Peale](/wiki/Rembrandt_Peale "Rembrandt Peale") "Porthole" portrait
or the [Charles Willson Peale](/wiki/Charles_Willson_Peale "Charles Willson
Peale") three-quarter-length portrait – over the mantel at the north end of
the room. A portrait of Andrew Jackson by [Thomas Sully](/wiki/Thomas_Sully
"Thomas Sully") hung in Lyndon Johnson's office, and in Ronald Reagan's,
George H. W. Bush's and Bill Clinton's. A portrait of Abraham Lincoln by
George Henry Story hung in George W. Bush's office, and continued in Barack
Obama's. Three landscapes/cityscapes by minor artists – _[City of Washington
from Beyond the Navy Yard](/wiki/City_of_Washington_from_Beyond_the_Navy_Yard
"City of Washington from Beyond the Navy Yard")_ by [George
Cooke](/wiki/George_Cooke_\(painter\) "George Cooke \(painter\)"), _Eastport
and Passamaquoddy Bay_ by Victor de Grailly, and _The President 's House_, a
copy after [William Henry Bartlett](/wiki/William_Henry_Bartlett "William
Henry Bartlett") – have adorned the walls in multiple administrations. _[The
Avenue in the Rain](/wiki/The_Avenue_in_the_Rain "The Avenue in the Rain")_ by
[Childe Hassam](/wiki/Childe_Hassam "Childe Hassam") and _[Working on the
Statue of Liberty](/wiki/Working_on_the_Statue_of_Liberty "Working on the
Statue of Liberty")_ by [Norman Rockwell](/wiki/Norman_Rockwell "Norman
Rockwell") flanked the _Resolute_ Desk in Bill Clinton's office, and did the
same in Barack Obama's.

Statuettes, busts, heads, and figurines are frequently displayed in the Oval
Office. Abraham Lincoln has been the most common subject, in works by
sculptors [Augustus Saint-Gaudens](/wiki/Augustus_Saint-Gaudens "Augustus
Saint-Gaudens"), [Gutzon Borglum](/wiki/Gutzon_Borglum "Gutzon Borglum"),
[Adolph Alexander Weinman](/wiki/Adolph_Alexander_Weinman "Adolph Alexander
Weinman"), [Leo Cherne](/wiki/Leo_Cherne "Leo Cherne") and others. In recent
administrations, traditional busts of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson or
Benjamin Franklin have given way to heads of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S.
Truman or Dwight Eisenhower. Western bronzes by [Frederic
Remington](/wiki/Frederic_Remington "Frederic Remington") have been frequent
choices: Harry S. Truman displayed _Fired On_ ; Lyndon Johnson displayed _[The
Bronco Buster](/wiki/Bronco_Buster "Bronco Buster")_ , as did Gerald Ford,
Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton, George W. Bush and Barack Obama.
Presidents Reagan and Bush added its companion piece, _Rattlesnake_.

President Harry S. Truman displayed works related to his home state of
[Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri"), illustrations of
[biplanes](/wiki/Biplanes "Biplanes"), and models of jet-airplanes. He hung a
large photograph of the White House portrait of Franklin D. Roosevelt, under
whom he had served as Vice-President, who died in office in 1945. President
Dwight Eisenhower filled the office walls with landscape paintings, as well as
a painting of [Robert E. Lee](/wiki/Robert_E._Lee "Robert E. Lee").[21]
President John F. Kennedy surrounded himself with paintings of naval battles
from the [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812"), photographs of
sailboats, and ship models. President Lyndon Johnson installed sconces on
either side of the mantel, and added the office's first painting by a woman
artist, _Franklin D. Roosevelt_ by [Elizabeth
Shoumatoff](/wiki/Elizabeth_Shoumatoff "Elizabeth Shoumatoff"). President
Richard Nixon tried three different George Washington portraits over the
mantel, and hung a copy of _[Earthrise](/wiki/Earthrise "Earthrise")_ – a
photograph of the earth taken from the moon's orbit during the [Apollo
8](/wiki/Apollo_8 "Apollo 8") mission – beside his desk. President Gerald Ford
displayed tasteful, conservative works; paintings that remained mostly in
place through the administrations of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. President
George H. W. Bush added [luminist](/wiki/Luminism_\(American_art_style\)
"Luminism \(American art style\)") landscapes. President Bill Clinton chose
the Childe Hassam and Norman Rockwell paintings mentioned above, along with
_Waiting for the Hour_ by William T. Carlton,[22] a genre painting showing
African-Americans gathered in anticipation of the [Emancipation
Proclamation](/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation "Emancipation Proclamation")
going into effect. President George W. Bush mixed traditional works with
paintings by Texas artists and Western sculptures. Following the September 11,
2001 attacks, British [Prime Minister Tony Blair](/wiki/Tony_Blair "Tony
Blair") lent him a [bust of Winston
Churchill](/wiki/Bust_of_Winston_Churchill_\(Epstein\) "Bust of Winston
Churchill \(Epstein\)"), who had guided Great Britain through World War II.
President Barack Obama honored Abraham Lincoln with the portrait by Story, a
bust by Augustus Saint-Gaudens, and a copy of the Emancipation Proclamation.
Below the proclamation was a [bust of Martin Luther King
Jr.](/wiki/Bust_of_Martin_Luther_King_Jr._\(Alston\) "Bust of Martin Luther
King Jr. \(Alston\)") by [Charles Alston](/wiki/Charles_Alston "Charles
Alston"),[23] and in the nearby bookcase was a program from the [August 28,
1963 March on Washington](/wiki/March_on_Washington "March on Washington"), at
which Dr. King gave his "[I Have a Dream Speech](/wiki/I_Have_a_Dream_Speech
"I Have a Dream Speech")."

### Redecoration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Redecoration")]

A tradition evolved in the latter part of the twentieth century of each new
administration redecorating the office to the President's liking. A new
administration usually selects an oval [carpet](/wiki/Carpet "Carpet"), new
[drapery](/wiki/Drapery "Drapery"), the paintings on the walls, and some
furniture. Most incoming presidents continue using the rug of their
predecessor until their new one is installed. The retired carpet very often is
then moved to the presidential library of the president for whom it was made.

The redecoration of the Oval Office is usually coordinated by the [First
Lady's](/wiki/First_Lady_of_the_United_States "First Lady of the United
States") office in the [East Wing](/wiki/East_Wing "East Wing"), working with
an interior designer and the [White House Curator](/wiki/White_House_Curator
"White House Curator").

### Alterations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Alterations")]

Since the present Oval Office's construction in 1934 during the administration
of President [Franklin Delano Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt
"Franklin Delano Roosevelt") the room has remained mostly unchanged
architecturally.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] More than any president, FDR left an impression
on the room and its use. Doors and window frames have been modified
slightly.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] A screen door on the east wall was removed
after the installation of air conditioning. President [Lyndon B.
Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson")'s row of wire service
Teletype machines on the southeast wall required cutting plaster and flooring
to accommodate wiring.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The Georgian style plaster ornament has been
cleaned to remove accumulated paint, and a series of electrified wall
[sconces](/wiki/Sconce_\(light_fixture\) "Sconce \(light fixture\)") have come
and gone.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Though some presidents have chosen to do day-to-day work in a smaller study
just west of the Oval Office, most use the actual Oval Office for work and
meetings. Traffic from the large numbers of staff, visitors, and pets over
time takes its toll. There have been four sets of flooring in the Oval Office.
The original floor was made of [cork](/wiki/Cork_\(material\) "Cork
\(material\)") installed over soft wood; however, President [Dwight D.
Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight D. Eisenhower") was an avid
[golfer](/wiki/Golf "Golf") and damaged the floor with his golf spikes.
Johnson had the floor replaced in the mid-1960s with wood-grain
[linoleum](/wiki/Linoleum "Linoleum"). In 1982, President [Ronald
Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") had the floor replaced with
quarter sawn oak and walnut, in a cross parquet pattern similar in design to
Eric Gugler's 1933 sketch, which had never been installed. In August 2005, the
floor was replaced again under President [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush
"George W. Bush"), in exactly the same pattern as the Reagan floor.

### Conservation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oval_Office&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Conservation")]

In the late 1980s, a comprehensive assessment of the entire house, including
the Oval Office, was made as part of the [National Park
Service](/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service")'s [Historic
American Buildings Survey](/wiki/Historic_American_Buildings_Survey "Historic
American Buildings Survey") (HABS).[24] Detailed photographs and measured
drawings were made documenting the interior and exterior and showing even
slight imperfections. A checklist of materials and methods was generated for
future conservation and restoration.
